title: 107_s1656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001". The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing veterans' compensation and pension claims accurately and timely. Concerns have been raised about the accuracy of claims processing, with new measurements showing lower accuracy rates than previously reported. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial, especially with a potential 30 percent workforce loss by 2003. The Veterans Benefits Administration faces challenges with accuracy and timeliness in processing claims. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial due to potential workforce loss. In 2001, the expected appeals processing time was 621 days, with a backlog of 533,029 claims in September 2001. Improvement of processing of veterans benefits claims is crucial due to challenges with accuracy and timeliness. In 2001, there was a backlog of 533,029 claims with an expected appeals processing time of 621 days. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan for improving claims processing within 90 days of this Act. The plan should focus on training adjudicators, enhancing accountability, and identifying errors to avoid delays in benefit payments. The plan for improving claims processing includes mechanisms to identify errors, strengthen data collection, implement a review system for accuracy, evaluate training impact, and set quantifiable goals. The Secretary must consult with veterans in developing this plan. The Secretary must consult with veterans organizations and other interested parties in developing the plan for improving claims processing. The plan includes mechanisms to identify errors, strengthen data collection, implement a review system for accuracy, evaluate training impact, and set quantifiable goals. The Secretary shall implement the plan 60 days after submission and may modify it with proper notification. Reports are to be submitted every six months to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs.
